name: nytimes
text:
RT @ByMikeBaker: West Coast wildfires:
• In Oregon, hundreds of homes destroyed.
• In Washington, a toddler dead and parents in critical condition.
• In California, some 2.5 million acres have burned — nearly twenty times what had burned at this time last year.

RT @nytgraphics: There are 55 days until Election Day.

Do you know
— when early voting starts in your state?
— when to request a mail-in ballot?
— the deadline to return it?
— when the presidential debates are?

We’ve got answers.

name: nytimes
text:
"We're targeting powerful men, which goes over badly in France."

Two women in the male-dominated world of French politics have come to define competing strains of French feminism. The generational divide has led to a fierce political fight. https://t.co/0C525ldVTR

name: nytimes
text: Anne Hidalgo, the second-term mayor of Paris, is often mentioned as a future presidential contender. She embodies a… https://t.co/7Q0qXNdIlh

name: nytimes
text: Alice Coffin, a longtime activist and newly elected city councilor, is part of a new wave that places violence agai… https://t.co/5023G2PGCk

name: nytimes
text: Christophe Girard, Hidalgo's deputy for culture, is a flashpoint between the two. The power broker has long supported the pedophile writer Gabriel Matzneff. Hidalgo defended Girard for months, until we reported he himself was accused of child sexual abuse. https://t.co/l58TlSZFD8

name: nytimes
text: For Coffin, removing Girard from power is at the heart of her feminism. She faced so many threats over it — some st… https://t.co/J3RHrpZVpj

name: nytimes
text:
The nature of the Girard case has reignited the debate over the goals of feminism in France, where the #MeToo movement was slow to take off.

Feminists are "always asked to reaffirm that we're not angry," Coffin said. "But, me, I'm very angry." https://t.co/0C525ldVTR
